items.title: Once high-flying proptech startups Divvy Homes and EasyKnock are the latest to struggle
items.author: Mary Ann Azevedo, Marina Temkin
items.summary:
- Many proptech startups are struggling due to a decline in investments, dropping from $11.1 billion in 2021 to $3.7 billion in 2023.
- Divvy Homes is being acquired by Maymont Homes, while EasyKnock has abruptly shut down amidst lawsuits and regulatory actions.
- Divvy raised over $700 million from investors but faced challenges with high interest rates affecting its business model.
- EasyKnock faced allegations of deceptive practices and financial struggles, leading to its insolvency by the time of shutdown.
- The real estate fintech sector may continue to face similar challenges in 2025 due to high interest rates and lack of funding.

items.title: DOJ confirms arrested US Army soldier is linked to AT&T and Verizon hacks
items.author: Zack Whittaker
items.summary:
- U.S. Army soldier Cameron John Wagenius was arrested on December 20, 2024, for transferring confidential phone records from AT&T and Verizon.
- The case is linked to previously indicted hackers who stole data from the cloud computing company Snowflake.
- The breaches affected many companies, with AT&T reporting that nearly all its customer call records were compromised.
- Wagenius claimed access to call logs of prominent figures and threatened to leak stolen files unless demands were met.
- He is currently in custody in Washington state, having been ordered detained on January 8, 2025.

items.title: TikTok says it will go dark Sunday unless Biden offers ‘definitive statement’
items.author: Anthony Ha
items.summary:
- TikTok claims it may no longer be available in US app stores unless Biden's administration provides definitive assurances against a ban.
- A Supreme Court ruling upheld a law that could effectively ban TikTok unless its owner, ByteDance, sells it by January 19.
- The Biden administration is deferring actions regarding TikTok's fate to the incoming Trump administration, which has sought to negotiate a resolution.
- White House Press Secretary stated TikTok should remain available under ownership that addresses national security concerns.
- TikTok warns it will be forced to go dark on January 19 if no assurance is provided from the Biden administration.

items.title: How victims of PowerSchool’s data breach helped each other investigate ‘massive’ hack
items.summary:
- On January 7, PowerSchool notified Romy Backus of a data breach affecting her school, discovered on December 28.
- Hackers accessed sensitive data, including Social Security numbers and medical information, from over 60 million students in around 18,000 schools.
- Backus initiated a response by investigating the breach and sharing findings with other affected schools through collaborative documents and group chats.

items.title: EV startup Canoo files for bankruptcy and ceases operations
items.author: Sean O'Kane
items.summary:
- Canoo has filed for Chapter 7 bankruptcy and will cease operations immediately.
- The company owes between $10 million and $50 million to fewer than 49 creditors and claims to have less than $50,000 in assets.
- Canoo struggled to secure funding, including from the U.S. Department of Energy, and had previously furloughed employees and idled its factory in Oklahoma.

Google begins requiring JavaScript for Google Search
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- Google mandates users to enable JavaScript to use Google Search to enhance security and performance.
- The requirement aims to protect against bots and spam, improving search result quality.
- Approximately 95% of websites use JavaScript, but the change could hinder accessibility for some users.
- Users disabling JavaScript represent less than 0.1% of searches, translating to millions of users without JS.
- The new policy could disrupt third-party tools that analyze Google Search trends and rankings.

items.title: Treasury sanctions Salt Typhoon hacking group behind breaches of major US telecom firms
items.author: Carly Page
items.summary:
- The U.S. government imposed sanctions on a China-based cybersecurity firm, Sichuan Juxinhe Network Technology, linked to the Salt Typhoon hacking group.
- Salt Typhoon is responsible for the largest telecom hack in U.S. history, affecting major companies like AT&T and Verizon.
- The group gained access to sensitive communications of U.S. officials and law enforcement data.
- OFAC also sanctioned Yin Kecheng, linked to a recent hack of the U.S. Treasury, which involved remote access to employee workstations using a stolen private key.

items.title: Malware stole internal PowerSchool passwords from engineer’s hacked computer
items.summary:
- A cyberattack at PowerSchool, discovered on December 28, threatens data of millions of students and teachers.
- Credentials were stolen from a PowerSchool engineer's computer by LummaC2 infostealing malware before the cyberattack.
- The engineer's device was hacked in January 2024, with logs indicating stolen passwords for various internal systems.
- PowerSchool stated the compromised account used for a breach lacked multi-factor authentication, a security feature now implemented.
- The breach exposed sensitive personal information including Social Security numbers and medical data of students.
- Affected school districts are assessing the extent of personal data theft, relying on shared efforts to search log files for evidence.

items.title: Bumble founder Whitney Wolfe Herd to reclaim CEO position in March
items.author: Lauren Forristal
items.summary:
- Bumble announces Whitney Wolfe Herd will return as CEO in March 2025 after stepping down in 2023.
- Wolfe Herd succeeds Lidiane Jones, who is leaving for personal reasons and will assist in the transition.
- The company is facing sluggish growth, with Q3 2024 revenue declining to $274 million despite an increase in paying users to 4.3 million.
- Bumble expects forthcoming Q4 report to exceed previous revenue forecasts of $256 million to $262 million and adjusted EBITDA of $70 million to $73 million.

items.title: Instagram Reels adds new features as TikTok is banned in the U.S.
items.author: Sarah Perez
items.summary:
- Instagram announced an update to Reels coinciding with the U.S. TikTok ban effective January 19.
- New features include seeing content liked by friends and a reply bar for direct responses.
- Meta aims to capture TikTok users, especially creators who may struggle to monetize on alternative platforms.

items.title: Instagram Reels rolls out new features for U.S. users as TikTok gets banned
items.author: Sarah Perez
items.summary:
- Instagram announced updates to its Reels feature as TikTok faces a ban in the U.S. starting January 19.
- New features will allow users to see content that friends have liked or commented on through a small banner.
- A new 'reply bar' will let users easily respond to their friends' interactions with Reels content.
- Meta aims to attract TikTok users, especially creators, following the ban.

items.title: Trump Comments on TikTok Ban
items.author: Sarah Perez
items.summary:
- Supreme Court upheld the law banning TikTok in the U.S. as of January 19.
- Donald Trump had a "very good" phone call with Xi Jinping discussing TikTok.
- Trump indicated he would make a decision on TikTok in the "not too distant" future after reviewing the situation.
- Supreme Court's decision to uphold the TikTok ban means it will be shut down unless sold.
- Uncertainty remains whether TikTok will cease operations entirely or continue for existing users.
